journal-meta.journal-title: Proceedings of the Institution of Mechanical Engineers, Part O: Journal of Risk and Reliability

title-group.article-title: Reliability demonstration based on accelerated degradation testing for unknown model parameters

contrib-group.aff: Laboratory of Science and Technology on Integrated Logistics Support, College of Mechatronics and Automation, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha, China

author-notes.corresp: Chun-Hua Zhang, Laboratory of Science and Technology on Integrated Logistics Support, College of Mechatronics and Automation, National University of Defense Technology, Changsha 410073, China. Email: luowei1021@163.com

abstract.p: Conventional reliability demonstration tests are becoming increasingly difficult to apply for high-reliability and long-lifetime products owing to the excessive test duration, which conflicts with the marketplace demands for decreased development time. Accelerated degradation testing has been strongly recommended to reduce test time, but few studies employ this method for reliability demonstrations. In this article, a test methodology based on accelerated degradation testing is developed to demonstrate the reliability target for the case in which the model parameters for the test plan design are unknown. In the proposed procedure, step-stress accelerated degradation testing is employed as a preliminary test to estimate the model parameters. The data from step-stress accelerated degradation testing are converted based on equivalent degradation criterion and then used to make decisions by the method of two steps accelerated reliability demonstration test. If there are not enough converted data to make a decision, an accelerated degradation testing as a complementary test is conducted to complete the demonstration according to the estimates of the model parameters from the preliminary test; the two steps accelerated reliability demonstration test method is applied. The proposed methodology incorporates step-stress accelerated degradation testing with two steps accelerated reliability demonstration test to permit the test duration to be reduced as much as possible. It is useful to demonstrate a high-reliability target at long mission times within a feasible test duration when the design parameters are unknown.

sec.title: Introduction
sec.p: The reliability demonstration test (RDT) is widely adopted to verify whether products have achieved reliability targets specified in the development and production process. The RDT is concerned with either accepting or rejecting a lot according to the data collected from the test. For an effective reliability demonstration, the test plan (also known as the variable sampling plan) should be appropriately designed. Literature on how to design the RDT plan differs in the choice of lifetime distribution and censoring scheme. Exponential1–6 and Weibull6–13 distributions are commonly assumed to describe the statistical properties of lifetime data in RDT. Time-censoring (Type I) instead of failure-censoring (Type II) is commonly adopted in RDT because many such tests are performed with strict time constraints.

Because of marketplace demands for increased reliability and decreased development time, conventional RDT at the use condition cannot demonstrate whether the products will achieve the high-reliability target at a long mission time within a feasible test duration. Accelerated life testing (ALT) has been widely adopted in RDT to reduce the test duration, which is termed accelerated life reliability demonstration test (ALRDT). The literature on ALRDT mainly differs in terms of the censoring scheme and whether the parameters of the acceleration model and the shape parameter for the Weibull distribution are known. This article primarily focuses on time-censored ALRDT. Cui14 proposed a test plan for time-censored ALRDT of a Weibull distribution with a known acceleration factor and shape parameter, and applied this test plan to demonstrate the reliability target of an electronic connector for space use. Kim and Yum15 provided a plan for time-censored ALRDT for a Weibull distribution with unknown shape and scale parameters, but with known acceleration factor. Seo et al.16 focused on the design of the test plan for time-censored simple constant-stress ALT (CSALT) with non-constant shape parameter, but the test plan design still depended on the pre-estimates of the parameters of accelerated model. Turner17 explored a reliability demonstration approach with quantitative ALT for power systems that was suitable for platform design and derived design with known and unknown acceleration factors, respectively; CSALT, as a preliminary test, was conducted to estimate the acceleration factor for the case in which the acceleration factor is unknown. In addition, some studies on ALRDT have involved the Bayesian method,18–19 and the test method under multiple stresses.20–22

Although the ALT can shorten the test duration, sometimes even ALRDT requires excessive test times. For products whose performances degrade over time, it is possible to measure these performances during the test. These degradation measurements can be used to predict whether the test unit will fail at the terminated time. Consequently, the test duration is further reduced. Sohn and Jang23 analysed the degradation data of keyboards through an acceptance sampling test, which indirectly proposed the sampling plan based on degradation data. Yang24 discussed how to design an optimum test plan for the degradation bogey test (also known as zero-failure testing) to demonstrate the reliability target, which considered the risks caused by sampling and degradation measurement fitting and depended on prior knowledge of the parameters of the degradation model. However, degradation testing instead of accelerated degradation testing (ADT) was considered. Acceleration may allow further reduction in the test time and effort, and should be used if the performance degrades slowly at the use condition. Very few studies exist on applying ADT in reliability demonstrations. One exception is Baussaron et al.,25 who described an approach to designing the degradation demonstration test plan using the Wiener process. However, the uncertainty caused by degradation extrapolation was not considered as part of the risk. In Baussaron et al.,25 the test plan depended on the estimates of the global severity factor and the parameters of the degradation model.

In this study, a test methodology based on ADT is developed for reliability demonstrations when the model parameters for the test plan design are unknown. Step-stress ADT (SSADT) is employed as a preliminary test to obtain the estimates of the model parameters and the data that are converted based on the equivalent degradation criterion and then used for decision-making. An ADT as the complementary test is needed to complete the demonstration if the converted data are not sufficient to make a decision. During the decision, the method of two steps accelerated reliability demonstration test (TSARDT) is applied, where the degradation measurements are utilised for decision-making and both the risk caused by sampling and the risk caused by degradation measurement fitting are considered.

The remainder of the article is organised as follows. First the preliminaries are described. The test methodology for reliability demonstrations based on ADT are then presented. ‘Illustrative example’ provides an example to validate the proposed method. Finally, conclusions are presented.

sec.title: Test methodology for the reliability demonstration based on ADT
sec.p: In the development and production phases, prior knowledge about the parameters of accelerated model and degradation model may be unavailable. For this case, a test methodology is developed to accomplish the demonstration. The flowchart of the test methodology is described in Figure 1.

caption.p: The flowchart of the test methodology.
ADT: accelerated degradation testing; SSADT: step-stress accelerated degradation testing; TSARDT: two steps accelerated reliability demonstration test.

sec.title: Reliability analysis
sec.p: The reliability analysis is indispensable to reliability demonstration testing for thoroughly reviewing the product to identify the failure modes and their effects by utilising the information in the development and production phases, and other pertinent information from other production lots or similar products. From the analysis procedure, the form of the lifetime distribution, the possible degradation model and the accelerated model will be determined.

sec.p:

It is noticed that the SSADT plan can only be determined by experience, because the optimal design of the SSADT depends on the prior knowledge of the model parameters,30–34 which are unknown before preliminary test. And the purpose of conducting the SSADT is to obtain the estimates of these parameters.

sec.title: Make the decision using the converted data by the TSARDT method
sec.p:
The TSARDT method includes two plans: 1) the optimum test plan for accelerated degradation reliability demonstration test (ADRDT); 2) the associated optimum test plan for time-censored ALRDT. For the TSARDT method, ADT with n units under stress
S
h
is conducted to demonstrate the reliability target. During the test, the degradation measurements are utilised to make decisions in terms of the ADRDT plan; if the decision cannot be made, only the failure information from the test is utilised to make decisions in terms of the associated time-censored ALRDT plan.
As the converted data have been obtained, the procedure of decision-making by the TSARDT method in preliminary test stage is:

list-item.p: design the optimum test plan for ADRDT using the converted data, if the plan is obtained, the decision can be made;
if the ADRDT plan cannot be obtained, the associated optimum test plan for the time-censored ALRDT is designed, and the decision-making is attempted.

sec.title: Complementary test
sec.p:
If the acceptability of the reliability of the products cannot be determined in the preliminary test, ADT under stress
S

sec.title: Illustrative example
sec.p:
Light emitting diodes (LEDs) have many applications, e.g. traffic signals and full-colour displays, and are desirable because of their high-brightness, low power consumption and high reliability.27 Assume that the specified reliability target of the LED to be demonstrated is

sec.title: The models
sec.p: The degradation of light intensity is the main failure mode for LEDs. When the light intensity falls below its threshold, the LED fails. The temperature is one of the main stresses that affect the degradation of light intensity at the use condition, which is often employed as the accelerated stress.27–28,35

The log-linear form of the true degradation model of the light intensity for the ith LED under the stress

sec.p:
According to the two plans for the TSARDT, 12 units that have survived the preliminary test and one added unit will undergo the ADT under stress
S
3
. It is concluded that the reliability level of the LEDs is closer to this target than to the other two targets. Because the greater reliability level deviates from the reliability target, a smaller sample size or number of measurements may be required for demonstration.

sec.title: Conclusions
sec.p: A test methodology was developed to demonstrate the reliability target at long mission times within a feasible test duration when the model parameters for the test plan design are unknown. To obtain the estimates of the model parameters, SSADT is employed in the preliminary test, which requires a shorter test time than constant-stress ADT. In addition, the converted data from SSADT can be used for decision-making, and they are moderately robust against the random error of the SSADT. As soon as there are enough degradation measurements to make a decision with a high degree confidence, the test duration required in the TSARDT is shorter than the one in the ALRDT. Therefore, the proposed procedure is attractive and useful because the test duration can be reduced as much as possible when the SSADT and TSARDT techniques are both employed. The validity of the proposed method is illustrated through an LED simulation example.

Furthermore, it is necessary to address the fact that the technical condition for the added units in the complementary test stage should be kept consistent with those tested in the preliminary test stage. In addition, there are two points that can be considered in the future. First, the degradation model in the proposed method focuses on the linear form, which may not be proper in some applications. Consequently, the test method involving other degradation models, such as the gamma or Weiner processes, can be studied. Second, other lifetime distributions, such as log-normal distribution and Inverse Gaussian distribution, can be used instead of Weibull distribution.
